content_scrubbed:
I had one class in college in which the professor refused to allow electronics.

I have horrible handwriting that even a private handwriting coach could not help as a kid. I was so pissed, but there were no alternatives. It was either take the class or wait an additional semester to graduate.

The class was a comparative study of novels and their film adaptations. While I only ended up taking an index code-worth of notes in a given day - and the material proved easy enough to bluff - it was a huge hassle.

I did not have any means of recourse, but the following things really pissed me off:

+ The professor was technologically-impaired. Whenever she wanted to use the projector or other media I was tapped. I gained a reputation as the go-to guy for troubleshooting in English, Humanities and History. Other students would point me out to instructors/professors and normally this was a delight (and I believe had a little to do with my grades).

+ She would *regularly* ask students to pull up IMDB on their phones. This made me very angry.

It was a small campus and the only minor (required) available for me was English. I knew the department well and there was one student that always showed up late, pulled out his laptop and had a lot of inappropriate content up at a given time.

The only times I wasn't taking notes with my laptop during class was during tests or pulling up tertiary material (such as images for Sans Culottes in History) relevant to the topics.

I am a veteran and was already pushing 30 when I began college. I survived 14 months in Iraq to earn my college money and I took school very seriously. To be lumped into the same category as that guy simply because *some* people cannot control themselves was disgusting. It reminded me of Basic Training when the entire platoon did push-ups because one person screwed up.

Your professor is doing it right. As long as students do not disrupt, then why should adults be treated in such a manner?

Ridiculous.

/end rant
